newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: Arms cuts talks intensify ahead of NATO summit.
newsitem.headline: Arms cuts talks intensify ahead of NATO summit.

text.p: Talks on updating a key treaty on conventional arms cuts in Europe have reached an intense phase in an effort to land a Russian deal ahead of NATO's summit in Madrid next week, a Western diplomat said on Thursday.

"We are engaged in an intense phase of negotiations and we are attempting to reach an agreement on basic elements of the treaty agreement in time for the Madrid summit," the source close to the talks said.

Thirty signatory states of the 1990 Conventional Forces in Europe (CFE) treaty, including the United States and Russia, agreed at a summit in Lisbon in December to restructure the pact to reflect the new face of Europe after the collapse of the Warsaw Pact and breakup of the Soviet Union.
A recent NATO-Russia accord on a new post-Cold War Security relationship has also given a push to the talks.
However, the talks' chances of success by next week hinge on the Russian attitude, the source said.
NATO has been pushing for national arms ceilings to replace group ceilings for force levels -- a suggestion that brought an initial cool response from Moscow.

But the source said Russia had recently indicated it saw no need to raise its equipment ceilings above the current level and that it may consider re-aligning its ceiling to the lower level of its existing holdings.
"The Russians have indicated that if the structure was right they could agree to have a future equipment ceiling at the level of their present holdings," he added.
